content: Singaporean educator (1918–2014) **Noel Evelyn Norris** (25 December 1918 – 15 February 2014) was a [Singaporean](/wiki/Singaporeans) educator best known for her association with [Raffles Girls' School](/wiki/Raffles_Girls%27_School_(Secondary)). She was also the first [principal](/wiki/Head_teacher) of [Crescent Girls' School](/wiki/Crescent_Girls%27_School). Norris was a volunteer in the [Royal Air Force](/wiki/Royal_Air_Force) during World War II and later became a Major in the [People's Defence Force](/wiki/Peoples_Defence_Force_(Singapore)) in charge of the Singapore Women Auxiliary Corps. ## Biography Norris was born Noel Evelyn Norris on 25 December 1918. She started primary school at [Raffles Girls' Primary School](/wiki/Raffles_Girls%27_Primary_School) in 1925. She attended Raffles Girls' Schools until 1933, when she studied for a year at [St. George's Girls School](/wiki/St._George%27s_Girls%27_School). She studied history at [Raffles College](/wiki/National_University_of_Singapore) and earned a degree in Education. Norris started teaching at [Bukit Panjang Primary School](/wiki/List_of_primary_schools_in_Singapore) in 1939, but when [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II) broke out, she went to India and [Ceylon](/wiki/Sri_Lanka) as a volunteer in the [Royal Air Force](/wiki/Royal_Air_Force) (RAF). In the RAF, she worked as a [librarian](/wiki/Librarian) in the Royal Air Force Library. When the war ended, she came back to Singapore and taught history at the [Raffles Girls' School](/wiki/Raffles_Girls%27_School_(Secondary)) (RGS) from 1946 to 1955. In 1956 she became the principal of the new [Crescent Girls' School](/wiki/Crescent_Girls%27_School). Norris came back to RGS to work as principal there until she retired in 1976. During her leadership at RGS, Norris developed extracurricular activities, including various sports and music programs. She also encouraged students to learn and understand various "[mother tongue](/wiki/Multilingual_Education)" languages in Singapore by conducting weekly assemblies in different languages each week. These assemblies rotated through [English](/wiki/English_language), [Malay](/wiki/Malay_language) and [Tamil](/wiki/Tamil_language) and other classes included [Mandarin](/wiki/Mandarin_Chinese). Norris also worked on [Ministry of Education](/wiki/Ministry_of_Education_(Singapore)) committees and helped revise the history [syllabus](/wiki/Syllabus). Norris also stayed active in the [People's Defence Force](/wiki/Peoples_Defence_Force_(Singapore)), eventually becoming a [Major](/wiki/Major_(rank)) of the Singapore Women Auxiliary Corps, and later took over the [National Cadet Corps](/wiki/National_Cadet_Corps_(Singapore)) girls' section. After retiring, Norris dedicated her life to community service and worked as a volunteer at the [Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals](/wiki/Society_for_the_Prevention_of_Cruelty_to_Animals) (SPCA). She also taught at the School for Retarded Children. In November 2011, Norris had a [stroke](/wiki/Stroke) and spent around six months in [Tan Tock Seng Hospital](/wiki/Tan_Tock_Seng_Hospital). After her discharge, a group made up of former students and faculty of Raffles Girls' School took care of her at her home in Brighton Crescent. Norris died on 15 February 2014. Norris was awarded the [Public Service Administration Medal](/wiki/Pingat_Pentadbiran_Awam) (Silver) in 1964. In 1977, she was awarded the [Long Service Medal](/wiki/Long_Service_Medal_(Military)_(Singapore)). Norris was inducted into the [Singapore Women's Hall of Fame](/wiki/Singapore_Women%27s_Hall_of_Fame) in 2019.
title: Evelyn Norris
